geninfo.para: This TSI applies to all models with Cummins engines.

A leaking air-to-air charge air cooler can adversely affect engine power and response time and cause high exhaust manifold temperatures. Engines that are allowed to operate with exhaust temperatures above the normal operating range can experience exhaust manifold and turbocharger failures. The exhaust components should be inspected any time a charge air cooler fails to meet the established air leak specifications. If the exhaust manifold and turbocharger are not inspected when the charge air cooler is replaced, engine performance may continue to be below normal because of damaged exhaust components.
Refer to CTS-5087 in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for charge air cooler air leak test instructions and specification.

The letter contains information to inspect the exhaust components when a charge air cooler is being replaced for failure to pass an air leak test. Any component that does not meet the inspection criteria should be replaced.

svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE

warning.para: To prevent an injury from a hot engine, allow the engine to cool before starting this procedure.

svcproc.para: With the exhaust manifold in place:

step1.para: Visually inspect the manifold sections for cracks or damage (Figure 1).
Visually inspect the sealing connection surfaces for damage (Figure 1).
Visually inspect the center section for damaged threads in the turbocharger mounting stud holes (Figure 1).
Loosen the turbocharger to allow inspection of the mating surfaces.
Visually inspect the turbocharger to exhaust manifold gasket surfaces and the mounting studs for cracks or damage (Figure 2).
Visually inspect the turbine and compressor housings (Figure 3).
If cracks that go all the way through the outer wall are found, the housing MUST be replaced.
Cracks in the mounting flange longer than 0.6 inch (15 mm) are NOT acceptable (Figure 4).
Cracks of any length that reach mounting holes are NOT acceptable (Figure 5).
Two (2) cracks MUST be separated at least 0.25 inch (6.4 mm) (Figure 6).
Cracks of any length that extend through the divider are acceptable only if they are separated by at least 0.50 inch (12.5 mm) (Figure 7).
